reviewText: I tried to like this movie, I really did, but it just didn't hit a chord with me. The movie is loosely based on the life of J.M. Barrie, the writer of the `Peter Pan' story. The writers of the movie manipulated the facts to get a warm fuzzy effect of the movie that I guess is supposed to leave you feeling inspired, though it didn't with me.Basically, the plot is rather mediocre. To sum up, Barrie meets a widowed woman and her son's in the park and they develop a friendship. Actually, I would consider Barrie more than just a `family friend'; he takes it a step further in my opinion. However, the writers of the movie made it obvious that their friendship was totally asexual (even with the mother). Essentially, the rest of the movie is him pretend-playing with these boys, thusly getting the inspiration for his famous play, `Peter Pan'. In the middle of this his wife gets annoyed that he's spending so much time with this family and leaves him (who could blame her). I wont say anything else about the plot because I don't want to spoil it, but that's pretty much it in a nut shell. The concept of the story is great; triumph of art, creativity, and playfulness over snootiness and growing-up.  However, I feel it was poorly executed in the movie. The acting and the visuals were pretty good, but the plot seriously lacked momentum.On a side note, it's funny how the movie completely mirrors Michael Jackson. You have a man who, for some reason, has this need to fill a void in his life by pretend-playing with young boys. This man completely refuses to `grow-up' and take on the normal responsibilities of adulthood such as tending to relationships and commitments.This movie is good for a rental. It's really nothing great.

reviewText: Marc Forster's "Finding Neverland" is another showcase for the impressive talents of Johnny Depp.  As is usually the case, the talented actor does not disappoint.Sir James Matthew Barrie's (Depp) newest stage play meets with disappointment.  While looking for inspiration for his next venture, he meets Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Kate Winslet) and her four sons.  There is an instant rapport between Barrie and the young men.  As he spends more time with them, Barrie's imagination is stimulated and he begins to develop a new work entitled "Peter Pan."  However, the vast amount of time he spends with the boys and their mother strains his relationship with his wife, Mary (Radha Mitchell) and raises the ire of Sylvia's mother, Mrs. Emma du Maurier (Julie Christie).The manner in which "Finding Neverland" blends fantasy and reality is befitting for a film about the author of "Peter Pan."  Yet the main reason for the film's success is due to its collection of outstanding performances.  Depp is outstanding and Winslet ably compliments him with a very strong turn of her own.  In addition, Freddie Highmore, Nick Roud, Joe Prospero, and Luke Spill are great as the young boys.  Mitchell, Christie, and Dustin Hoffman round things out with strong supporting work.  Yet, "Finding Neverland" succeeds mainly because of Depp.  He immerses himself so well in the role of Barrie that it never feels like he is just an actor playing a part.  Chalk up "Finding Neverland" as another feather in his cap.

reviewText: PETER PAN was never my favorite childhood story. It has come to life in a number of versions on stage and screen, but the story of the boy who never wanted to grow up never appealed to me. Who knows, maybe I need to release my inner child and that is why I react negatively to it. Since I am not the greatest PETER PAN fan, I had no string desire to see FINDING NEVERLAND. I read reviews in the paper, some of which lauded the work, others which gave it less than favorable grades. It was not until a woman in a writing workshop I attended praised the film that my interest was peaked. She said it was something all writers would relate to and it was well done. Since she, like many of the participants of the workshop could tell an interesting story and appreciate a good story as well, I decided I should go see it. I put it off until after it was nominated for various Academy Awards and decided I had to see it before the Oscars.I will not say that FINDING NEVERLAND deserves to receive all of the Oscars that it is the running for, but it does deserve all of the nominations it has received. It is a beautiful film with a riveting story. It tells the story of the writer J.M. Barrie and the relationship he has with the widow Sylvia Llewellyn Davies and her four young sons.  Barrie is in an unhappy marriage and his friendship with Sylvia, as well as his fascination with her sons brings him out of a slump. The relationship resulted in his writing the play PETER PAN. The main focus of the film is the relationship between Barrie, Sylvia, and her sons. Little attention is paid to the marital conflict, nor is undue attention paid to the rumors regarding the friendship of Sylvia and Barrie (e.g. Is it Platonic? Why is he so mesmerized by the boys?). Both situations are mentioned so the viewer is aware that Barrie's world is not Neverland. While some could se this as a glossing over of the conflict in the film, the brief attention speaks powerfully and allows the viewer to be aware of the whole situation, which in turn allows the viewer to see how this family inspired what many consider to be a great work by a genius.The acting is superb. Once again Johnny Depp shows he is a great character actor and Kate Winslet is wonderful as Sylvia. Rahda Mitchell plays Mary Barrie, J.M.'s wife with great skill. She is neither a vixen nor a shrew, which makes the marital difficulties easy to believe. Two of Hollywood's greats, Julie Christie and Dustin Hoffman, play supporting roles which are integral to the success of the film. Hoffman is the theatre owner Charles Frohman who produces Barrie's plays and has misgivings about PETER PAN. Julie Christie plays Sylvia's mother Emma du Maurier. Emma is a socialite who appears to be snobby, but we see as the film progresses that it is out of concern for her daughter and grandchildren. Perhaps the characters who have the most emotional pull in the film are the Llewelyn Davies boys George, Jack, Peter, and Michael played by Nick Roud, Joe Prospero, Freddie Highmore, and Luke Spill respectively. While Highmore's Peter is endearing, viewers' hearts go out to Roud's George, who cannot be a Peter Pan like figure when his mother is dying. The setting for the film is beautiful. Early twentieth century England comes to life in a realistic manner, and the props and stage equipment in the theatre are also accurate for the time period. The music is moving and adds an emotional element to the film.So will it get Best Picture? Maybe, but the competition is steep. I would not expect to see Depp receive best actor in place of Jamie Foxx as Ray Charles, though in another year Depp would be a contender for the award. It could easily win awards for art direction, music, adapted screenplay and costume design. If there was an Academy Award for moving the heart, FINDING NEVERLAND would easily win.Enjoy!!!
summary: It's Easy to See Why This Film is an Oscar Contender

reviewText: "Finding Neverland" is that rare gem of a movie that takes its audience seriously.  So many of the movies out of Hollywood are geared towards the 16 to 25 year old male perspective.  Action, dumb plot, stupid characters, etc.  "Neverland" is a movie that doesn't pander to emotion.  It doesn't show us yet another unnecessary action scene.  And it doesn't make every relationship obsessed with sex.What you get with "Neverland" is a movie that takes you to another time and gives you insight into the mind of a great writer and the experiences which influenced him.  It is a patient movie, more interested in creating a tone and place to help us understand the concepts of Neverland, imagination, and reality.While perhaps not the focus of the director (and probably unnoticed by most viewers), "Neverland" is also a refreshing depiction of a male character dealing with children.  While Barrie is depicted as being child-like, he is still a grown man with an adult's ability in relating to children.  Far too often we're inundated with media images of the stupid father figure, the doofus, who doesn't have a clue.  With Depp's characterization of Barrie we see a man who can play with children and yet still be an adult.Johnny Depp, almost as matter of course, once again delivers a performance that is all the more amazing given his body of work as a whole.  This the same man who did "Pirates of the Caribbean," "What's Eating Gilbert Grape," and a dozen other movies in widely divergent character roles.  And Kate Winslet seems to be only getting better with age, both in ability and beauty.There seems to be a number of reviewers claiming that "Neverland" is slow or that it's pretentious.  If you enjoy well made movies you can ignore these comments.  Of course, don't fall prey to the hype, either.  "Finding Neverland" might not become your most favorite film, but it is worth both viewing and owning as a DVD.  I can't say that about too many films these days.
summary: A movie about the child-like J.M. Barrie that treats its audience like adults

reviewText: Finding Neverland is a bit of a charmer that's much better than it has any right to be but not nearly as good as it could have been with a bit more nerve. Whereas The Lost Boys (no, not the vampire one), Andrew Birkin's BBC take on the relationship between J.M. Barrie and the Llewellyn-Davies children who inspired his greatest work, was all sombre darkness and little light, Marc Forster's film could do with a little more shading, and it's a tribute to Johnny Depp's abilities that he manages to avoid turning Barrie into Tinkerbell or, worse, Mrs Doubtfire. His understated charm gives the whimsy wings even when the direction and photography fails to quite convince. It's the smaller moments that really convince - the genuinely touching moment with a widow after the premiere of Peter Pan beautifully touches on the sense of loss that fuelled the play, as does the moment he notices the oldest of the children suddenly growing up.The other players meet with mixed fortunes. Kate Winslett is just Kate Winslett, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, Freddie Highmore impresses as Peter, Dustin Hoffman is reliably worldworn, but Julie Christie's wicked stepmother is always on the brink of parody (but then Christie never was much of an actress). Rhada Mitchell tries hard to avoid turning Mrs Barrie into a heartless stereotype, but the script is so busy celebrating Barrie's free spirit that it only briefly touches on the way he shuts her out of his imagination. The DVD also includes a wonderful in-character out-take of Depp expressing his admiration for the capacity of his dog's bladder that is worth the price of the disc on its own.

reviewText: This story is based on James Barrie, the playwright best known for Peter Pan and it is one of the best films that I've seen this year, despite receiving next to no hype or marketing push.James Barrie (Johnny Depp) is a playwright, successful enough to have a nice house with servants, and a beautiful wife (Radha Mitchell). Still, his marriage seems distant and he is bothered by the mediocrity of his creative output. On opening night, people complement him on his terrible plays and he knows they are just trying to be nice.One day while sitting on a park bench, he encounters three adolescent boys, who he quickly befriends. He invites them over for dinner and also solidifies a friendship with their mother, played by Kate Winslet, much to the disappointment of his wife and her mother, the stern, protective Julie Christie. The boy's father died from cancer and to some extent, his becomes their playmate, without trying to replace their dad. At the same time, his wife becomes increasingly disenchanted that her husband is spending so much time with another woman and her children.As his friendship grows with the boys and her mother, he begins to develop a play, loosely based about them. While initially met with skepticism in the planning stages, the play ends up becoming Barrie's most famous creation.While less visually fantastic than last year's Big Fish by Tim Burton, Finding Neverland has its own tastefully limited special effects, but it outshines Burton's film in its amount of sheer heart.I actually ended up seeing this film since I arrived too late for the film I originally wanted to see. At the end of Finding Neverland, I was not even slightly surprised to see the audience burst into applause. It was also nice to see that the film was sold out.The acting is well done without being spectacular. I enjoyed Johnny Depp's performance, but he didn't play the role with an extraordinary amount of charisma. Some people will see this as a failing, but I think a genuine performance is better than glitzy but shallow one. One of the children is particularly strong, playing the role of Peter. He's the youngest but at the same time he's complex, cynical and surprisingly mature.
summary: stirs emotions, makes you feel alive

reviewText: Finding Neverland is the story about how Sir James Barrie inspired by a widowed family and wrote the all time classics Peter Pan.James (Johnny Depp) was having a serious writer block and his last work flopped badly. He was in need of inspiration and his marriage was on the rocks. Fate brought him to meet the widowed family of Sylvia Davies (Kate Winslet), whose deceased husband left her 4 boys on her own. Through interactions with the boys, each having their own character, James weaved together a masterpiece that originally was thought of insane, but then turned to be the classic that everyone now still reads and enjoys.Johnny Depp gave a spectacular performance again as James Barrie. Not that he put on an accent for the role, but the way he re-created James Barrie as a living character again. The struggle he exhibited for his career, the way how he wanted to solve the marriage problem and yet tried to avoid it, the straight innocence and purity for his care of the boys, and his crazy and imaginative way of telling his stories. Johnny Depp handled every single aspect of the character with a magic touch and yet you could see any side of his character fell apart from the main body. The scenes in which he told Sylvia his childhood secret. and the last scene with Peter were just so well done that you just got drawn into the world of James Barrie and felt that you were there.Kate Winslet as Syvia Davies gave a good turn of her character choice compared to her other movies. She re-lived the life of a woman who contributed her life for her 4 sons. She was worn out by life, she was living through grief, and yet she still wanted to believe that imagination could be solution to problems. You could feel her pain inside her glances from time to time. The character choice was great.The supporting cast was also great. Nick Roud who played George and Freddie Highmore who played Peter were two of the more outstanding ones in terms of performance opportunities. Both were boys who were forced to grow up because of the mishappening at home, but deep inside they wish they could still live a life as a boy of their parents. They are the muse for James and thus eventually named the main character in his play after Peter.Finding Neverland is about the retention of childhood, imagination and creativity in the grown up world. It is the desire to remind the audience about, what matters inside your mind and make believe is the energy of life, no matter what the situation is. This is why James Barrie reserved seats for a group of kids on the opening night, despite the opposition of the theatre manager. It was only through the laughter of the kids that, the audience felt relax and could actually enjoy the imagination and creativity provided by the Neverland.The movie itself has quite a bit of sad elements in it, however, because of what we saw the characters were trying to do, even after weeping (yeah you could hear people weeping in the cinema) you would still feel very good about the movie. The subtle positive energy delivered by the movie would make you to remember it, feel it and appreciate it. The soundtrack accompanying the movie is also marvellous. The tune just fit perfectly into the world of the movie and helped carry the emotion to the audience vividly.Finding Neverland could easily be one of the best movies of the year, without shedding blood, cutting limbs, or any 100 million dollar special effect. In fact, just looking at how older day's theatre tried to expand their imagination on their stage design is already a pleasure. It is not a moving to be missed during this post holiday season.

reviewText: Johnny Depp, dead cert for Oscar nomination of 2005, plays J. M. Barrie, the creator of Peter Pan.  'Finding Neverland' is largely based on the real-life events surrounding the man and the four boys and a widow who inspired the writer to give birth to one of the world's most beloved character, and how the friendship between them gave the magical inspiration to the writer.  And the film has that magical quality too.After the critical disaster of the stage production (which was also a financial disaster to his patron Charles Frohman played by Dustin Hoffman) J. M. Barrie meets the boys and their mother in the park while walking his dog.  The widowed lady is Sylvia Davies (equally superb Kate Winslet), to whom Barrie is attracted despite the existence of his neglected wife Mary (Radha Mitchell).  In this curious but still interesting way, the magical creation of Peter Pan started.While Barrie comes to be an unofficial member of Sylvia's family, we realize that there is too much innocence on the side of Barrie, who can see that imagination is a great thing when playing with the kids yelling like pirates in the garden, but who cannot see that he (and Sylvia) is violating the social mores of English middle-class.  Nor can he understand the broken heart of his own wife.The film takes great liberty with the biographical facts, so don't believe that eveything depicted here is historically accurate.  The story is too neat, with the events compressed within 100 minutes.  And some characters -- such as Ian Hart as Conan Doyle or Julie Christie as Mrs. Emma DuMaurier -- should be given more substantial or complex roles.But Johhny Depp gives accomplished portrait as Barrie who refused to see certain things in life, and created the character who refuses to grow up, with very warm and tender touch.  Frankly, I find his Scottish accent slightly annoying, and Barrie's naivete that could be more harmful to the Sylvia's family is toned down to make his personality and the film itself more accessable.  He loves Sylvia, it is certain, but not in the way that reminds you of the idea of infidelty.However, the fine acting from Depp and Winslet overcomes these  strangely vague points, which could be fatally damaging in the hands of other lesser actors.  As it is, the film remains very engaging throughout, as the heart-felt portraits of the people who needed each other to survive the pains that life can give.
summary: Believing in Neverland: Another Accomplished Work from Depp

reviewText: FINDING NEVERLAND is a short biopic about author J.M. Barrie and how he came to write the play PETER PAN, which has gone on to become one of the most famous works of theatre and children's literature ever. The movie opens as Barrie watches his latest play being performed, displaying his anxiety. The play is a flop. From there the movie goes on to show Barrie's first meeting of the Llewelyn-Davies family, how he became friends with the family, the estrangement and eventual divorce from his wife, and how the Llewelyn Davies children inspired the creation of PETER PAN.Johnny Depp portrays Barrie. As is usually the case, Depp is in excellent form and is well deserving of the Oscar nomination he received. Kate Winslet plays the widowed and dying Sylvia Llewelyn Davies. Winslet has had a career of hits and misses. Her performance in FINDING NEVERLAND is one of her better performances, displaying a full range of her skills, rather than just typecasting her as a beautiful young romantic or as a naked crazy woman (or as the case in TITANIC the beautiful young naked woman). Dustin Hoffman has a supporting role in the film as does Ian Hart. However, it is the performance of Freddie Highmore as Peter Llewelyn Davies that is most outstanding. Highmore's performance is remarkable and is just as extraordinary as Haley Joel Osment in THE SIXTH SENSE. It's a shame that Highmore didn't gain an Oscar nomination (though he did become friends with Depp-who he shares a birthday with-and Depp had him cast as Charlie Bucket in the upcoming Tim Burton version of CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY).FINDING NEVERLAND is a touching film that doesn't degrade itself to schmaltz. The film plays with certain details of Barrie's life to make the movie more dramatic (for example, Arthur Llewelyn Davies was still alive when Barrie first met his family; there were five sons instead of four). Still, it does a great job at showing how Barrie's experiences with the Llewelyn Davies inspired the creation of Peter Pan. Most of the time the film also shies away from the mushy sentimentality that so many other films of similar type succumb to. FINDING NEVERLAND shows the good along with some of the bad and that even though a person may "need to go on pretending. Until the end.", sometimes we can only dream on a budget.
summary: "Ah, yes, well... we're dreaming on a budget."

reviewText: 'Finding Neverland' is a fictionalized account of play-write J.M. Barrie's inspirations that would result in possibly his most famous work, 'Peter Pan.'  This inspiration is the Llewelyn Davies family, composed of the widowed Sylvia (Kate Winslet), her cynical mother (Julie Christie), and her four boys, including the "young adult" Peter (Freddie Highmore), increasingly apathetic and depressed following his father's death.  The story is one of magic, as is the film.  However, despite the opportunity for more interesting subject matter, director Mark Forster's new film feels quite processed; one can tell the cheese-loving Miramax produces.  There are no difficulties, nothing challenges the audience; even the performances given by an appropriately softened Depp and the disappointingly plain (it's not like she was given much to work with) Kate Winslet seem to settle at one horizon and cease to expand upon their respective characters or develop nuance.  But despite its short-comings, 'Finding Neverland' is an often-times endearing piece of work, proving perfect in production value; there are even delicious supporting roles that seem to exist only to spice up the screen with the likes of Julie Christie and Dustin Hoffman, both doing well with small, underwritten roles.  The highlight of the film, though, is young Freddie Highmore, who, despite his young age, manages to fully emote and elicit honest emotional response (in a key break-down scene, Highmore nearly had me in tears).  He, among other reasons, will draw many to the film (I expect 'Neverland' to rank high on weekend box office charts).  Mark Forster sets the film at a generously even pace, so 'Neverland' will keep its audience awake.  But the screenplay falls short of making its themes of imagination vs. cynicism entirely convincing, as there is lack of character development throughout, and many adults herein feel much too black-and-white during a rather quick group transition from stern to jovial.  Though I recommend 'Neverland' to some, I am still a bit reserved as many may be disappointed in its lack of intense feel-good moments and "inspirational" schmaltz.  Unlike the play 'Peter Pan' itself, Forster's own Neverland is too simple and restricted to be entirely moving.
summary: More like three-and-a-half stars: reserved recommendation.

reviewText: At the beginning of "Finding Neverland", struggling playwright J.M. Barrie (Depp) is in a rut, as he has been creating uninspiring and boring plays. The film suggests he tried to write to his audience, rather than remaining true to his own worldview and letting everyone see his unique form of genius. Barrie discovers the secret to unlocking his brilliance when he develops a deep platonic love for a widow and her four young boys and draws on them as his muse. From his time with the fatherless family, the world is given the play "Peter Pan".Although Barrie develops a powerful and strangely non-sexual love for the mother of the boys (Kate Winslet), it is his relationship with her children that touches his heart and opens a path toward emotions he has repressed for years. Seeing the innocence in them reminds Barrie of a simpler time in his life when dreams came true and magic lurked around every corner.He immerses himself in their lives, inventing imagination outlets for the boys and driving them to believe in dreams and wonder. What Barrie feels for the children is hard to explain (and in today's time would be viewed with a few raised eyebrows). He develops the kind of pure, unconditional love that convinces others it must be tainted in some way. No man can love a stranger's four boys so much.Like "Shakespeare in Love", the audience gets to see how real life events become iconic moments from literature. The film's lasting images include beautiful dissolves from reality to imagination, as Barrie's mind alters and sculpts experiences to fit his play. One unforgettable image begins with the four boys jumping on their beds and (in Barrie's mind) becomes the famous scene from "Peter Pan" where the children float out of their bedroom.While the film makes important declarations as to the power of wide-eyed youthful imagination and challenges viewers to recapture the wonder of childhood, it at times becomes laborious to watch. The only real conflict in the film is painfully artificial and clichéd (disapproval from Barrie's wife and the boys' grandmother). Indeed, it is an inspirational and magical film, but it just seems to be lacking a little something extra to make it great.
summary: Moving and Magical, but overall Unremarkable

reviewText: Whatever involves you, involves your emotions. Whatever involves you in Peter Pan, involves you in Barrie's emotions. Many of those are happy, but some are not simple things.As with any of Depp's movies, this one admits of many readings. The first story is on the surface: Barrie befriends a family in harsh straits, and they inspire him to stories that live far beyond their intended audience.Another reading finds Barrie as the eternal child, never really at home in the adult person. He just wants to do whatever he does best, even if the grownups (like him, sort of) don't get it. Yet another, grimmer view of this story finds much to question in this man's fascination with little boys, an echo of Lewis Carroll's dark side.All the levels present themselves at once - maybe more than once, as scenes keep coming back to the viewer, even days later. It's a well-made movie, and an emotionally powerful one (if that's what you want). It's an uplifting view of the finest flower of loving creativity, but carries a waft of the manure around its roots.It also has a number of scenes that conspicuously jerk at one's tears. Some of them even work. They're not the ones I remember later, though.//wiredweird

reviewText: The magic of the "Peter Pan universe" is something that most children experience at some time in their lives.  The thrill of staying young forever, flying away to distant lands, and battling pirates is one that can easily capture the imagination of the young.  "Finding Neverland" is the story of how James Barrie created that magical universe that has stood the test of time.For a basic plot summary, "Finding Neverland" sees struggling playwright James Barrie (Johnny Depp) introduced to Sylvia Davies (Kate Winslet), a widow with four young children, on a chance encounter at a local park.  While forming a bond with Sylvia and especially her playful children, Barrie begins to realize the power of "play" and "imagination" and begins to incorporate those elements into a new play about a boy who never grows up.This film is very successful on two different levels:1. The backstory on Barrie/Davies is very interesting.  I knew nothing about it going in, so I can't speak to the accuracy of all the events depicted, but it sure seems as if Barrie was truly inspired by the Davies children.2. For fans of the Peter Pan narrative, seeing the story come together bit by bit is a visual and emotional treat.  It is kind of strange to think of the Pan story as anything but pure childhood escapism fiction, but this movie shows us how it was quite real to the actors, theater-goers, and producers of the day.Only helping matters is the solid acting by Depp and Winslet, who are both so "classically trained" in acting (I believe they have both done much theater) that their casting is perfect in this period piece.Overall, then, "Finding Neverland" is a fun, informative film for fans of the Peter Pan cannon.  It will bring out your emotions, humor, and sense of history while viewing.

reviewText: Movies are just one means of enjoying flights into fancy, escaping from the everyday into a world of fantasy, where all things are possible. Imagination rules the day, and with imagination, there are no rules.The on-screen story of J. M. Barrie (played by Johnny Depp) as the author/playwright of Peter Pan is a delightful flight into another world, if not always one that is removed from the pains and bruisings of reality. Inspired by (if on occasion departing from) true events, the story about the writing of the story shows the evolving friendship between Barrie and the widow Davies (played by Kate Winslet) and her four young sons.Barrie meets the family while sitting on a park bench writing ideas for a play. I was charmed from the moment Depp seamlessly left his creative work to give in to a moment of play with the boy curled up below the park bench. While in reality I have watched such attempts from adults to come down to the level of children in relating to them as playmates appear a mix of patronizing at worst, clumsy at best, Depp, as Barrie, suffers no such stumbling. Surely, neither did Barrie, or he would not have created such a work of playfulness, even inspiring a psychological term of "the Peter Pan syndrome" to refer to adult men who refuse to grow up.But there is a child in all of us, isn't there? There should be. Just as there is the wisdom of the ancients, and perhaps the two go hand in hand, as playmates. Barrie soon spends his days, when he is not writing, playing with the four boys. Games of cowboys and Indians, heroes and villains, pirates and kings. Play unlocks Barrie's creativity to eventually become the groundbreaking play, Peter Pan (with Dustin Hoffman as curmudgeonly theatre producer who goes along with a begrudging trust in Barrie's talent, even while spouting doubt after doubt). Somewhat in the background to all of this play is the widow Davies, and one never quite understands whether there is a romantic bond forming or simply one of deeply felt friendship. We never see the relationship between the two adults develop beyond the latter, although love is evident. Barrie already has a wife, and we see her pain, too, as she loses her husband to the widow's family and her own marriage unravels. Neglected, she finds another companion, and the Barrie marriage is over.These are the pangs of reality. They, too, show up in Peter Pan on the stage. There is death, there is loss, there is grief. But there is also the magic of taking flight, "real" and of the spirit. The on stage story parallels the story off stage.We know already that the play, Peter Pan, becomes a classic, and rightfully so. But I found myself often watching the story behind the story unfold with the bittersweetness of nostalgia and longing. I watched the magic of creativity, of art. I saw the human connections made and unmade, fragile and tender, between adult and adult, adult and child. I saw a world, real and imaginary, that has so often become lost to us, as we increasingly replace imagination with a crass and ugly reality, or, perhaps more accurately referred to as--indulgence.Depp is exquisite. I've come to expect that from this actor. Winslet is convincing, offering not too much, not too little, with excellent timing. The four boys, especially young Peter, are wonderful. Were there more such children today! Were there more such adults who knew how to play.Recommended.
Title: Finding Neverland
